description: From Middle English prety, preti, praty, prati, from Old English prættiġ (“tricky, crafty, sly, cunning, wily, astute”), from Proto-Germanic *prattugaz (“boastful, sly, slick, deceitful, tricky, cunning”), corresponding to prat (“trick”) +‎ -y. Cognate with Dutch prettig (“nice, pleasant”), Low German prettig (“funny”), Icelandic prettugur (“deceitful, tricky”). For the semantic development, compare canny, clever, cute.

entries.meaning: Pleasant to the sight or other senses; attractive, especially of women or children. [from 15th c.]
examples: To escape a violent beating from sailors to whom he has sold a non-functioning car, Jerry takes his stepfamily for a holiday in a trailer park miles away, where, miraculously, young Nick meets a very pretty young woman called Sheeni, played by Portia Doubleday.

entries.meaning: Of objects or things: nice-looking, appealing. [from 15th c.]
examples: 'Petit Posy' brassicas  […]  are a cross between kale and brussels sprouts, and are really very pretty with a mild, sweet taste.

entries.meaning: (often derogatory) Fine-looking; only superficially attractive; initially appealing but having little substance; see petty. [from 15th c.]
examples: Damned by the Socialists as "traitors to the working class," its leaders were decried by Tories as "faceless peddlers of politics with a pretty little trinket for every taste."
"What did you do to your hair?" The answer could be worth a pretty penny for L'Oreal.

entries.meaning: (dated) Excellent, commendable, pleasing; fitting or proper (of actions, thoughts etc.). [from 16th c.]
examples: ‘This new fashion of introducing the candidate's children into an election contest is a pretty one,’ said Mrs. Panstreppon; ‘it takes away something from the acerbity of party warfare, and it makes an interesting experience for the children to look back on in after years.’

"Nay, not I; it is a pretty thing to expect me to wash them; you may take them back again, and say, as Sally had them before, she may wash them now, for me; I am not going to be 'Jack at a pinch,' I can tell you."

entries.meaning: Somewhat, fairly, quite; sometimes also (by meiosis) very.
examples: By the Sheets you have sent me to peruse, the Account you have given of her Birth and Parentage is pretty exact [...].

entries.meaning: A pretty person; a term of address to a pretty person.
examples: I'll get you, my pretty, and your little dog, too!
We'll stop at the knife store and look at the sharp pretties.

verbs.description: pretty (third-person singular simple present pretties, present participle prettying, simple past and past participle prettied)
